rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 Welcome to the enrichment lab.}
{\rtf1 This is one of my favorite labs ever.}
{\rtf1 Why?}
{\rtf1 Because it's one of the things\par organizations routinely do not}
{\rtf1 do. Wait, did I say organizations?\par I also met vendors vendors.}
{\rtf1 I met everybody, nobody does this stuff.}
{\rtf1 And I don't understand why, because, well,}
{\rtf1 as you'll see in the lab,}
{\rtf1 assume you get an alert\par and it's a standard alert.}
{\rtf1 This IP is being attacked\par by this IP address. And the,}
{\rtf1 the alert name is, you know,\par possible command and control.}
{\rtf1 Well, what actually happened,}
{\rtf1 who did it is the box infected\par and wait, Justin don't,}
{\rtf1 you need a SOAR platform to\par automate all those SOAR is great.}
{\rtf1 But your SIEM should be able to\par do a lot of this work for you}
{\rtf1 via the log ingestion.\par After the logs are ingested.}
{\rtf1 There's so many use cases for\par context, enrichment and enhancements,}
{\rtf1 and this can save you tons\par of time, tons of money,}
{\rtf1 increase your detection capabilities Oh,}
{\rtf1 and help you deal with false positives\par and your alert. You have alert fatigue.}
{\rtf1 The additional enrichment will\par help you filter out noise.}
{\rtf1 So in this lab, here's what we're\par doing. We have two alerts, you know,}
{\rtf1 standard Snort IDs, intrusion\par detection, system alerts,}
{\rtf1 and they come in and we read them\par and you'll see, it's like, ah,}
{\rtf1 it could be bad. You have no clue. You\par have no clue. But by the end of the lab,}
{\rtf1 you'll know, are they both malicious?\par Are they both? Benign is one,}
{\rtf1 benign is one malicious.}
{\rtf1 And you literally can see\par exactly how I done this.}
{\rtf1 And you should build to do this and\par other SIEMs, not just with logs,}
{\rtf1 actually like we're\par going to do in the lab.}
{\rtf1 So hopefully this drives home what\par enrichment is and why it's so valuable.}
{\rtf1 So let's jump right in.}
{\rtf1 So in the enrichment lab,}
{\rtf1 what we're going to\par start with is two alerts.}
{\rtf1 One deals with a exe download\par or DLL download on windows.}
{\rtf1 And one is a PDF possible PDF\par dictionary entry with hex,}
{\rtf1 hex, ASCII replacement,}
{\rtf1 neither one of those screams\par boxes infected bad things have}
{\rtf1 happened, but they're both alerts\par and an alert really is supposed to be}
{\rtf1 investigated. So what's going\par on? They're kind of bland.}
{\rtf1 So what we're going to do,}
{\rtf1 the first thing we would do is\par we'd run Logstash and just see what}
{\rtf1 fields we're dealing with. So the\par config file here, and by the way,}
{\rtf1 you can always open these up.}
{\rtf1 So if I were to paste this in}
{\rtf1 and I'm just going to change it so that\par instead of running Logstash I opened the}
{\rtf1 file.}
{\rtf1 You can see the exact\par code that I'm doing here.}
{\rtf1 We'll bring that up.}
{\rtf1 Here we go.}
{\rtf1 And you'll see in here,\par I'm using generator,}
{\rtf1 which basically tells Logstash to act\par as if it received that log and then}
{\rtf1 I'm parsing it. I'm going to\par do a view toggle word wrap.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 So basically all I'm doing for these is\par I'm using rejects pattern matching and}
{\rtf1 I'm parsing out the fields, which\par should result here in a second,}
{\rtf1 have them printed, parsed\par out to the screen log stash,}
{\rtf1 unfortunately is Java based.}
{\rtf1 So it takes a little bit to start up\par the newer version. That's seven, nine,}
{\rtf1 and later is substantially\par faster. Unfortunately,}
{\rtf1 that's not what's in the labs\par and every time I update it,}
{\rtf1 I have to be careful with\par all the recordings and stuff.}
{\rtf1 So we're not yet on that version.\par So we'll give that a second to run,}
{\rtf1 and this is going to print\par out all the fields we have.}
{\rtf1 So it's just an easier to view output.}
{\rtf1 The reason I'm doing that is what\par I'm trying to see is if I get}
{\rtf1 alerts, what data do I have\par and how can I interact with it?}
{\rtf1 How can I automatically ask questions\par and have the SIEM answer it before an}
{\rtf1 analyst ever sees the data?}
{\rtf1 And this is where I always start cause\par different alerts from different systems}
{\rtf1 contain different data. So I'm\par going to go ahead and look at this.}
{\rtf1 So we see two alerts.}
{\rtf1 I see the hex ASCII PDF.\par I've got a destination IP,}
{\rtf1 I've got a source IP. I can see\par what interface it triggered on.}
{\rtf1 And I see source port\par deskport the other one.}
{\rtf1 I see the exe download and again,\par same information desk, IP source, IP.}
{\rtf1 So given this information, how\par could I make this log better?}
{\rtf1 That's kind of what we're asking.\par That's why we're starting here. Well,}
{\rtf1 I have external IP addresses. We\par just not send a source IP field.}
{\rtf1 It doesn't matter in a intrusion\par detection or like a network}
{\rtf1 detection prevention engines.}
{\rtf1 The way the rule is written\par is how it would alert.}
{\rtf1 So given that the source port is 80\par and the source IPS and external IP,}
{\rtf1 that's probably actually the\par destination, not the source IP.}
{\rtf1 I know that's really confusing. Don't,\par don't, don't read into that too much,}
{\rtf1 but depending on how the rule was written,}
{\rtf1 the way it's looking at the network\par flow, it could actually flip it.}
{\rtf1 And that's probably what's happening\par here. But if I have an IP address,}
{\rtf1 well, I can do a geo lookup.\par I can take this IP address.}
{\rtf1 And if I have DNS logs,}
{\rtf1 I could see if there was an answer that\par resolve to that to figure out what the}
{\rtf1 real domain name is. And we\par can keep going with this.}
{\rtf1 So let me go ahead and get the\par next step running. So next,}
{\rtf1 what we're going to do is we're going\par to do a Geo enhancement, run that}
{\rtf1 while that's running.}
{\rtf1 I'll go ahead and bring up that file\par just so I can show you what we're doing}
{\rtf1 here. It's effectively the same\par file. We're just adding to it.}
{\rtf1 So you know what I was each step,}
{\rtf1 I'm just adding a little\par bit more enrichment here.}
{\rtf1 I'm doing running a geo IP\par using a ASN database and a city}
{\rtf1 database. These both come from\par Maxmind, and you can get them for free.}
{\rtf1 There's a good chance. Your SIEM\par already has them baked in any way,}
{\rtf1 but this is going to grab\par city, state latitude longitude,}
{\rtf1 as well as if you do the\par ASNs ASN information.}
{\rtf1 So now I'll have the same\par fields we had a second ago,}
{\rtf1 but I'll also have additional\par context around geographic}
{\rtf1 data. So we'll give this a second to run,}
{\rtf1 you know, notice the way I'm using this.}
{\rtf1 It basically runs through the\par log and then stops log stash.}
{\rtf1 This is great for testing.}
{\rtf1 You notice here,}
{\rtf1 it loaded up the geo databases and\par kind of scan through pretty quickly.}
{\rtf1 But now look at the logs. They're\par bigger. Let me start with the top one.}
{\rtf1 So now if I look at the exe or deal,\par all download, which is right here,}
{\rtf1 I can tell it came from a IP\par address that Google inc has}
{\rtf1 registered because of the ASN\par information specifically that}
{\rtf1 IP is registered in\par California in mountain view.}
{\rtf1 And so well, what is that?}
{\rtf1 The external IP in question\par is an IP in Google's world.}
{\rtf1 If I look at the other\par alert, the weird PDF hex,}
{\rtf1 exc ASCII replacement,\par well that external IP,}
{\rtf1 this one that one's\par hosted in Amazon's space.}
{\rtf1 So when their ASN at this point,}
{\rtf1 I can't really tell anything more\par because the doesn't mean it came from}
{\rtf1 Amazon. It doesn't mean the\par other one came from Google.}
{\rtf1 It means that the IP address,}
{\rtf1 the web servers in question\par are hosted in Amazon or Google.}
{\rtf1 Now there's a difference\par between Google site like}
{\rtf1 www.google.com and someone hosting a}
{\rtf1 virtual machine or a container\par in Google's cloud infrastructure.}
{\rtf1 So I can't yet tell are these actually\par from Amazon or Google or someone hosting}
{\rtf1 within their cloud environments, but\par this is additional context. So give them,}
{\rtf1 let's keep going this time.}
{\rtf1 Let's actually pull in\par the DNS query behind}
{\rtf1 this. So I'm running this\par DNS conf, I'll bring that up.}
{\rtf1 So what we're doing here\par is we're still doing geo,}
{\rtf1 but now we're adding in\par a cross correlation here,}
{\rtf1 right here. I'm basically saying, Hey,}
{\rtf1 if something is tagged as an\par external source or destination}
{\rtf1 cross query elastic search,}
{\rtf1 cause that's my backend SIEM\par database for this lab and say, Hey,}
{\rtf1 in the DNS logs,}
{\rtf1 was there a query that had an answer\par that mapped to that external IP,}
{\rtf1 whether it was a source IP or a desk IP,}
{\rtf1 the tag of external source or external\par destination that was added here}
{\rtf1 basically is doing a simple\par RFC 1918 rejects check against}
{\rtf1 the source IP field. If it matches\par it, tags it as a internal source,}
{\rtf1 if it doesn't and marks it as an external\par source. And then right above that,}
{\rtf1 I do the same thing for destination IP.}
{\rtf1 So it's basically cross\par correlating the DNS information.}
{\rtf1 Let's see how that shows.}
{\rtf1 So what I should now have are the\par two original or it's geo information}
{\rtf1 and the domain names that were\par actually used at the time,}
{\rtf1 there was a connection and here we go.}
{\rtf1 Now I have the PDF hex.}
{\rtf1 ASCII is mapped to trackmy}
{\rtf1 package-com.biz. Well,}
{\rtf1 trackmypackage-com.biz}
{\rtf1 seems somewhat sketchy, could\par be normal. We don't know,}
{\rtf1 but there it is.}
{\rtf1 The other one is dealing\par with a download from}
{\rtf1 dl.google.com. That to me,}
{\rtf1 points to this being more\par benign in nature. Why?}
{\rtf1 Because I don't think I'm\par going to actually get attacked\par and served malice from}
{\rtf1 Google's own sites.}
{\rtf1 dl.google.com is Google's download\par site where you would download like a}
{\rtf1 Chrome Google drive, things like\par that. So now I've got this alert,}
{\rtf1 I'm leaning more towards a\par false positive in this one.}
{\rtf1 I'm at probably leaning towards\par it's more sketchy or more suspicious}
{\rtf1 because that's an odd query\par for a PDF download could be}
{\rtf1 legit. We don't actually know.}
{\rtf1 So let's keep going in the last step.}
{\rtf1 I'm just showing where if I\par could correlate this against\par some windows data that}
{\rtf1 we can get for free could also be\par worked with like EDR solutions or}
{\rtf1 other, uh, endpoint suites.}
{\rtf1 Then all of a sudden\par I can get even better.}
{\rtf1 So this is adding a couple\par more auto correlation rules in,}
{\rtf1 and please keep in mind if you keep\par going farther and farther with this,}
{\rtf1 as much as I want, as long as\par I know what questions to ask.}
{\rtf1 So at the end of this, we've got geo IP,}
{\rtf1 we've got DNS information\par and then here I've added}
{\rtf1 underneath the queries were well,}
{\rtf1 if I know the source IP and ports,}
{\rtf1 let me just do word wrap here for this.}
{\rtf1 If you have that information,}
{\rtf1 and I know whether the IDS\par was written the normal way,}
{\rtf1 or if it reversed the socket\par information, I can account for that.}
{\rtf1 And so I'm correlating this to\par windows event, ID three for Sysmon,}
{\rtf1 which is network connections. Well,}
{\rtf1 what that's going to do is\par it's going to let me see, well,}
{\rtf1 the same network sockets, source\par IP destination IP, source port,}
{\rtf1 destination port exists in Sysmon}
{\rtf1 I can now figure out what process\par made the connection, what its ID was,}
{\rtf1 what host name, what user\par and what user domain.}
{\rtf1 And if I have that information,}
{\rtf1 I can correlate that to event ID\par 11 for Sysmon and pull out if it}
{\rtf1 interacted with a file somehow,}
{\rtf1 and I can technically use other system\par on data for like registry, keys, DLLs,}
{\rtf1 and things like that. So again, you\par can go as far with this as you want.}
{\rtf1 And if the connection\par was, was not flipped well,}
{\rtf1 let's do basically doing the same\par thing. So now when I look at the logs,}
{\rtf1 our ending result looks like this for the}
{\rtf1 policy exe download, is this\par malicious suspicious or benign?}
{\rtf1 Well, let's walk through this.}
{\rtf1 I'm seeing Internet Explorer\par connect to this IP and}
{\rtf1 that IP maps to where's the\par dl.google.com That here it is,}
{\rtf1 dl.google.com.}
{\rtf1 So this workstation connected to\par deal that google.com using internet}
{\rtf1 Explorer and they downloaded Chrome set up}
{\rtf1 dot exe.}
{\rtf1 The user that did this was Justin\par Henderson using active directory's,}
{\rtf1 uh, Azure AD, so hybrid AD.}
{\rtf1 And so what's the story probably. Well,}
{\rtf1 it's probably Internet Explorer being\par used for the one thing that's good for,}
{\rtf1 downloading a new browser.}
{\rtf1 So this one looks pretty much benign\par and we have tons of data to help}
{\rtf1 us with that hypothesis.\par So it's hosted in Google.}
{\rtf1 The actual domain was dl.google.com.}
{\rtf1 Internet Explorer is downloading\par Chrome set up and probably benign.}
{\rtf1 Let's take a look at the other one.}
{\rtf1 This one was that PDF hex, ASCII,}
{\rtf1 same computer, but it went\par out to trackmypackage-com.biz}
{\rtf1 using Microsoft edge. So\par a more modern browser.}
{\rtf1 And what did it do? Well,}
{\rtf1 that was ran from the\par same user, same domain.}
{\rtf1 And it did pull down this PDF called\par shipment notification five, five,}
{\rtf1 five dot PDF. This one to\par me, I would probably say,}
{\rtf1 I don't know if it's malicious.\par I don't know if it's benign,}
{\rtf1 but I have more details than I started\par with. It's still suspicious to me.}
{\rtf1 This could be a phishing PDF,}
{\rtf1 unclear what the details,}
{\rtf1 help my analysts speed\par things up substantially.}
{\rtf1 So for this lab, we could have kept going,}
{\rtf1 but I don't want you to spend hours\par doing this back home. I do write,}
{\rtf1 build this out, right,}
{\rtf1 but can you see the advantage\par of having alerts being}
{\rtf1 bland parsed,}
{\rtf1 but unenriched versus\par having context filled}
{\rtf1 data,}
{\rtf1 plus all this additional information\par you could use as a filter}
{\rtf1 so that your analysts never see it. Like\par if you knew one of like dl.google.com,}
{\rtf1 you're not too worried about it.}
{\rtf1 You could have applied it as a filter\par to help you with alert, fatigue.}
{\rtf1 So as you get more data, you can\par make better informed decisions.}
{\rtf1 That's what this enrichment\par lab is all about.}
